titleInfo.title: Essays on the Causal Effects of Criminal Justice Reforms on Crime

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation uses natural experiments to study three policies and their effect on crime outcomes: the effect of medical marijuana laws on prison re-entry, the effect of gun bounties on gun violence, and the effect of ShotSpotter on crime. Since 1996, 38 states have passed medical marijuana laws (MML). In this chapter, I leverage variation in the timing of state MML policy to estimate the effect of legalizing medical marijuana on recidivism and explore whether distribution via dispensaries or home cultivation differentially affects recidivism. Utilizing data on over nine million prison releases between 1990 and 2015, I estimate that the most regulated MML policy (dispensaries and no provisions for home cultivation) decreases overall recidivism by 3.3 percentage points, while an MML that distributes via both dispensaries and home cultivation increases recidivism by 2.1 percentage points which suggests that home cultivation may lead to increases in illegal distribution of marijuana. Gun bounty programs are a local measure that offer $1,000 in exchange for anonymous tips regarding gun law violations. Between 2000 and 2019, 17 counties in Florida implemented a gun bounty program. Leveraging variation in the rollout of gun bounty programs and utilizing recent advances in difference-in-differences literature, I estimate that gun bounties lead to a 10%-30% decrease in robberies involving a firearm and a 20%-26% reduction in motor vehicle thefts. There is also evidence suggesting there may be effects on domestic violence, although more analysis is needed. Cost-benefit analysis suggests the program has a net social benefit of at least $3.5 million per year. Considering that this program is seldom utilized outside of Florida, there is potential to increase public safety, reduce gun violence, and reduce the social burden of crime through the implementation of more gun bounty programs. ShotSpotter is a gunshot detection technology used by 200 cities in the United States. Despite its widespread use, there still remains questions about its efficacy in reducing crime. This paper analyzes geotagged crime data from Miami-Dade County to estimate the effect of ShotSpotter on firearm murders. Using propensity score matching, synthetic control, and synthetic difference-in- differences and aggregating crime to two different geographical levels, I find little evidence of a statistically significant effect on firearm murder, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary, or motor vehicle theft.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Economics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Carl Kitchens, Professor Directing Dissertation; Joseph Schwartz, University Representative; Luke Rodgers, Committee Member; Cynthia Yang, Committee Member.
